Comment: Awkward, but not that bad, yet.

I think exd5 is better here.
I think exd5 is better here.
I think exd5 is better here.
Hangs the pawn at g2.
Should have played Qxg2, forking the rook and knight. Play would likely follow Rg1 Qxh3, Rxg7 Qxh2, Bf1.
Much better would have been Bf3.
Again! Missed Qxg2! Only now Black has the bishop on d6 to contribute.
Error after error after error. White could defend with the simple O-O. Now there is a pawn on c4 that White must worry about defending.
A threat, but not as much as Qxg2! as would have been playable earlier.
You have to admire White's use of this in-between move, but it does allow for Qc6, renewing the threat on g2, all while the a1 rook is still attacked.
Good.
Now that Black's queen no longer guards d4, 8. d4 would have been better.
Finally Black capitalizes on White's weakness.
10. d4 is pointless now. Furthermore, White's knight is hanging! Play would follow: Qxc3+, Kf1 Qh3+, Ke1 Bxh2, and either Rh1, Rf1, or Rxg7, perhaps.

Too early, but I guess it kindof still works.
Black can now easily get out of the pin and save his bishop after Qxc3+, Kf1 Bd6 (or Bf4).
This is easily countered with Rf1.
...or that, but the king is now exposed and the queen has poorer access along the d file. Plus the f pawn is hanging.
Better is Qxf2, pinning the bishop to the king...
Better is Qxf2, pinning the bishop to the king...
Better is Qxf2, pinning the bishop to the king...
The queen simply moves back to its original square. Black loses a tempo as a result. She now threatens check instead of a pin, but it's easily defensible.
The queen simply moves back to its original square. Black loses a tempo as a result. She now threatens check instead of a pin, but it's easily defensible.
Black still can't castle because the knight would be hanging. Protect it, and castling would leave it pinned to the rook.
